THE COLSTRIP WATER TREATMENT PLANT
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN


REASONS FOR 

?    Section 112? of the Federal Clean Air Act (CAA) Amendments of 1990 was published by EPA on June 20, 1996. This rule is otherwise known as the Risk Management Plan Rule (RMP Rule) (40 CFR part 68). The rule requires that each affected business develop and implement a Risk Management Program. The goal of the RMP is to prevent accidental releases of toxic or flammable substances that can cause serious harm to the public health and the environment and to mitigate the effects of releases that do occur. It will ensure that responders and the citizens of Colstrip are aware of any hazards associated with an emergency at the Colstrip Water Treatment Plant.

THE ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONCE POLICY

?    IN AUGUST 1998, A PROCESS SAFETY MANAGEMENT PLAN WAS WRITTEN AND ADOPTED. 
o    The purpose is to establish normal procedures for handling hazardous chemicals that are regulated by the Occupation Safety and Health Administration.  This procedure has been written for compliance to 29 CFR 1910.119.
o    This procedure identifies what requirements are necessary for the continuous use of chlorine gas as an oxidizing biocide at the Colstrip Water and Wastewater Treatment Plants. 
o    This procedure applies to all employees that work at the City of Colstrip who operate or support the operation of the Water and Wastewater Plants.
o    A Copy of the PSMP is kept on file at the Water Treatment Plant and at City Hall.

OUR FACILITY AND THE SUBSTANCES HANDLED

?    THE COLSTRIP WATER TREATMENT PLANT IS LOCATED NORTHWEST OF THE TOWN OF COLSTRIP AT 45 53.39N AND -106 38.02W, JUST EAST OF CASTLE ROCK LAKE. 
o    The Colstrip Water Treatment Plant is operated by the City of Colstrip and employs state certified water and wastewater operators to install, operate, maintain, and comply with environmental regulations.
o    Review of existing processes at the Colstrip Water Treatment Plant has identi

fied chlorine as the only chemical that is regulated. There is a maximum inventory of 4000 lbs of chlorine onsite. The chlorine is liquefied under pressure and is packaged in the form of two 1 ton cylinders. Chlorine is dangerous as a gas or liquid. Chlorine gas is used in the treatment process as a disinfectant killing greater than 99.99% of all waterborne pathogens. It is also used in the optimization of the filtering process.
o    Chlorine gas irritates the respiratory system, mucous membranes, eyes, and skin.  Breathing air containing high concentrations of chlorine can result in death.  The OSHA permissible exposure limit (PEL) and the threshold limit value (TLV) are 0.5 ppm. The EPA toxic endpoint is based on 3 ppm. Liquid chlorine can cause skin and eye burns upon contact.  When open to the air, liquid chlorine vaporizes to chlorine gas expanding 460 times when changing from the liquid state to the gaseous state. 
o    Proper handling can mitigate the hazards of exposure to chlorine.  Essentially "proper handling" of chlorine means using operating and maintenance practices which will keep it confined in shipping containers, storage tanks and plant piping.  Chlorine can be dangerous when it escapes to the atmosphere.  Chlorine has a pungent odor and is detectable at very low concentrations (approximately 1 ppm) and initially alerts workers of a potentially dangerous situation.  Employees must be aware that with time people lose their ability to smell chlorine because it numbs the olfactory nerves.  Chlorine gas is heavier than air so the gas will stay close to the ground when dispersed by the wind and it will accumulate in low places.
o    Employees whose work includes the operation or maintenance of chlorination equipment must have adequate knowledge of its chemical hazards and be properly trained. 
 
 
THE WORST CASE AND ALTERNATE RELEASE SCENARIOS

?    THE WORST CASE SCENARIO IS BASED ON THE EPA'S RMP*COMP MODEL.
o    Involves a vessel leak from a 1-ton cylinder. A relea

se of 2000 lbs of chlorine at 200 lbs/min for 10 minutes and a wind speed of 1.5 m/sec. The distance to the toxic endpoint is a 1-mile radius from the Water Treatment Plant. 
o    The effected area is approximately 2.4 square miles and encompasses more than half of Colstrip. Anyone inside this area would need to be evacuated. The area includes everything from just south of Willow Avenue to the power plants on the east to Chisholm street on the north. The industrial park is included as well as is all of the Cimarron area. The estimated population within this area is 1500 people and includes Isabel Bills Elementary School and the Frank Brattin Middle School. The Colstrip High School and Pine Butte Elementary schools are on the outer perimeter but might want to be included in an evacuation as a precautionary measure.
 

?    THE ALTERNATE SCENARIO IS BASED ON THE EPA'S RMP*COMP MODEL
?    Involves a vessel leak from a 1-ton cylinder. A release of 450 lbs of chlorine at 7 lbs/min for 60 minutes and a wind speed of 3 m/sec. The distance to the toxic endpoint is a .1-mile radius from the Water Treatment Plant.
?    Since the effected area is only a tenth of a mile a release of this nature would not reach State Highway 39 or any residential areas. There aren?t any people within this area except perhaps Water Treatment personnel and perhaps personnel at the PPL pump house. Recreational users of Castle Rock Lake around the dam area, although outside this perimeter, may also need to be warned of the hazard.
 

THE ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

?    THE KEY TO PREVENTING ACCIDENTS IS HAVING A GOOD PREVENTION PROGRAM
o    The Colstrip Water Treatment Plant complies with all applicable federal and state rules and regulations including the OSHA PSM rule.
o    Colstrip Water Treatment Plant personnel follow all manufactures guidelines when  operating and maintaining the chlorinating equipment.
o    All chlorine-handling procedures are followed as set down by the Chlorine Institute. An Emergency

Kit "B" is maintained onsite for emergency repair of the one-ton containers.
o    It is required that all venders are OSHA compliant and that all delivery personnel use safe handling practices.
o    A chlorine leak detector is used and is connected to an alarm system. The alarm system alerts City of Colstrip personnel to any problems within minutes of any leak.
o    The chlorine containers are tested and certified by the chlorine venders on a regular basis.
 

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

?    THERE HAVE BEEN NO REPORTABLE ACCIDENTS IN THE LAST 5 YEARS

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

?    The City of Colstrip is in the process of evaluating alternatives to the use of chlorine gas. This would eliminate the storage of chlorine ton cylinders and the subsequent risk and would eliminate the need for a risk management plan.
